page.title: List of movements of the human body

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{expand list|date=November 2013}} {{refimprove|date=November 2013}} {{Anatomical lists |expanded=general}} The list below describes such skeletal movements as normally are possible in particular joints of the human body. Other animals have different degrees of movement at their respective joints; this is because of differences in positions of muscles and because structures peculiar to the bodies of humans and other species block motions unsuited to their anatomies. ==Arm and shoulder== {{main|Sternoclavicular joint|Acromioclavicular joint|Shoulder joint}} ===Shoulder=== {{main|Shoulder}} {| class="wikitable" align="center" |+ Movements of the shoulder joint.{{cite book | title = Clinical Anatomy by Systems | first = Richard S. | last = Snell | publisher = Lippincott Williams & Wilkins | pages = 427–428 }} |- ! Movement || Muscles || Origin || Insertion |- ! rowspan="5" valign="center" | [[Flexion]]
(150°–170°) | Anterior fibers of [[Deltoid muscle|deltoid]] | [[Clavicle]] | Middle of lateral surface of [[Body of humerus|shaft of humerus]] |- | [[Clavicle|Clavicula]]r part of [[Pectoralis major muscle|pectoralis major]] | Clavicle | Lateral lip of [[Intertubercular sulcus|bicipital groove]] of humerus |- | Long head of [[biceps brachii]] | [[Supraglenoid tubercle]] of [[scapula]] | rowspan="2" | [[Radial tuberosity|Tuberosity of radius]], [[Antebrachial fascia|Deep fascia of forearm]] |- | Short head of [[biceps brachii]] | [[Coracoid process]] of [[scapula]] |- | [[Coracobrachialis muscle|Coracobrachialis]] | Coracoid process | Medial aspect of shaft of humerus |- ! rowspan="3" valign="center" | [[Extension (kinesiology)|Extension]]
(40°) | Posterior fibers of deltoid | [[Spine of scapula]] | Middle of lateral surface of shaft of humerus |- | [[Latissimus dorsi muscle|Latissimus dorsi]] | [[Iliac crest]], [[lumbar fascia]], spines of lower six [[thoracic vertebrae]], lower 3–4 [[rib]]s, [[Inferior angle of the scapula|inferior angle of scapula]] | Floor of bicipital groove of humerus |- | [[Teres major muscle|Teres major]] | [[Lateral border of the scapula|Lateral border of scapula]] | Medial lip of bicipital groove of humerus |- ! rowspan="2" valign="center" | [[Abduction (kinesiology)|Abduction]]
(160°–180°) | Middle fibers of deltoid | [[Acromion]] process of scapula | Middle of lateral surface of shaft of humerus |- | [[Supraspinatus muscle|Supraspinatus]] | [[Supraspinous fossa]] of scapula | [[Greater tubercle]] of humerus |- ! rowspan="4" valign="center" | [[Adduction]]
(30°–40°) | [[Human sternum|Sternal]] part of pectoralis major | [[Human sternum|Sternum]], upper six [[costal cartilage]]s | Lateral lip of bicipital groove of humerus |- | Latissimus dorsi | Iliac crest, lumbar fascia, spines of lower six thoracic vertebrae, lower 3-4 ribs, inferior angle of scapula | Floor of bicipital groove of humerus |- | [[Teres major muscle|Teres major]] | Lower third of [[Lateral border of the scapula|lateral border of scapula]] | Medial lip of bicipital groove of humerus |- | [[Teres minor muscle|Teres minor]] | Upper two thirds of lateral border of scapula | Greater tubercle of humerus |- ! rowspan="3" valign="center" | [[External rotation|Lateral rotation]]
({{nowrap|in abduction: 95°;}}
{{nowrap|in adduction: 70°}}) | [[Infraspinatus muscle|Infraspinatus]] | [[Infraspinous fossa]] of scapula | Greater tubercle of humerus |- | Teres minor | Upper two thirds of lateral border of scapula | Greater tubercle of humerus |- | Posterior fibers of deltoid | Spine of scapula | Middle of lateral surface of shaft of humerus |- ! rowspan="4" valign="center" | [[Internal rotation|Medial rotation]]
({{nowrap|in abduction: 40°–50°;}}
{{nowrap|in adduction: 70°}}) | [[Subscapularis muscle|Subscapularis]] | [[Subscapular fossa]] | [[Lesser tubercle]] of humerus |- | Latissimus dorsi | Iliac crest, lumbar fascia, spines of lower 3-4 ribs, inferior angle of scapula | Floor of bicipital groove of humerus |- | Teres major | Lower third of lateral border of scapula | Medial lip of bicipital groove of humerus |- | Anterior fibers of deltoid | Clavicle | Middle of lateral surface of shaft of humerus |} The major muscles involved in retraction include the [[rhomboid major muscle]], [[rhomboid minor muscle]] and [[trapezius muscle]],{{DartmouthAnatomy|shoulder/surface/scsurface4}}[http://www.exrx.net/Articulations/Scapula.html#anchor71014 Scapula & Clavicle Articulations] whereas the major muscles involved in protraction include the [[Serratus anterior muscle|serratus anterior]] and [[Pectoralis minor muscle|pectoralis minor]] muscles.{{DartmouthAnatomy|shoulder/surface/scsurface3}}[http://www.exrx.net/Articulations/Scapula.html#anchor70306 Animation at exrx.net] ===Sternoclavicular and acromioclavicular joints=== {{main|SC joint|AC joint}} {| class="wikitable" | '''[[Scapula]] and [[Clavicle|clavicula]]''' ||Abduction (Protraction) || Adduction (Retraction) |- || || Depression || Elevation |- || || Rotation Upward (Superior Rotation) || Rotation Downward (Inferior Rotation) |} ===Elbow=== {{main|Elbow|Proximal radioulnar joint|Distal radioulnar joint|Humeroulnar joint}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Joint !! From !! To !! Description |- | [[Humeroulnar joint]] || [[trochlear notch]] of the [[ulna]] || [[trochlea of humerus]] || Is a simple [[hinge-joint]], and allows of movements of flexion and extension only. |- | [[Humeroradial joint]] || [[head of the radius]] || [[capitulum of the humerus]] || Is a [[ball-and-socket joint]]. |- | [[Superior radioulnar joint]] || [[head of the radius]] || [[radial notch]] of the [[ulna]] || In any position of flexion or extension, the radius, carrying the hand with it, can be rotated in it. This movement includes[[pronation]] and [[supination]]. |} ===Wrist and fingers=== {{main|Wrist|finger|thumb}} {| class="wikitable" |[[Wrist]] & [[Midcarpals]] ||Flexion ||Extension / Hyperextension |- || ||Adduction (Ulna Deviation) ||Abduction (Radial Deviation) |} ==== Movements of the fingers ==== {| class="wikitable" |[[Metacarpophalangeal]] ||Flexion ||Extension / Hyperextension |- || ||Adduction ||Abduction |- |[[Interphalangeal articulations of hand|Interphalangeal]] |Flexion |Extension |} ==== Movements of the thumb ==== {| class="wikitable" |[[Carpometacarpal]] ([[thumb]]) ||Flexion ||Extension |- || ||Adduction ||Abduction |- || ||Opposition | |- |[[Metacarpophalangeal]] (thumb) |Flexion |Extension |- | |Adduction |Abduction |- |[[Interphalangeal articulations of hand|Interphalangeal]] (thumb) |Flexion |Extension / Hyperextension |} ==Neck== {{main|Atlantooccipital articulation|atlantoaxial articulation}} {| class="wikitable" |[[Neck]] ([[Atlantoccipital]] & [[Antlantoaxial]]) ||Flexion ||Extension / Hyperextension |- || ||Lateral Flexion (Abduction) ||Reduction (Adduction) |- || ||Rotation |} ==Spine== {{main|Cervical spine|thoracic spine|lumbar spine}} {| class="wikitable" |[[Cervical spine]] ||Flexion ||Extension / Hyperextension |- || ||Lateral Flexion (Abduction) ||Reduction (Adduction) |- || ||Rotation | |- |[[Thoracic spine]] |Flexion |Extension / Hyperextension |- | |Lateral Flexion (Abduction) |Reduction (Adduction) |- | |Rotation | |- |[[Lumbar spine]] |Flexion |Extension / Hyperextension |- | |Lateral Flexion (Abduction) |Reduction (Adduction) |- | |Rotation | |} ==Lower limb== {| class="wikitable" |[[Hip]] (acetabulofemoral joint) ||Flexion ||Extension |- || ||Adduction ||Abduction |- || ||Transverse Adduction ||Transverse Abduction |- || ||Medial Rotation (Internal Rotation) ||Lateral Rotation (External Rotation) |} === Knees === {{Main|Knee}} {| class="wikitable" |[[Knee]] ||Flexion ||Extension |- || ||Medial Rotation (Internal Rotation) ||Lateral Rotation (External Rotation) |} {| class="wikitable" |Ankle ||Plantar Flexion ||Dorsi Flexion |} ===Feet=== {{main|Intertarsal|metatarsophalangeal|Interphalangeal articulations of foot}} {| class="wikitable" |[[Intertarsal]] - (foot) ||Inversion ||Eversion |- || ||Plantarflexion |} {| class="wikitable" |[[Metatarsophalangeal]] (toes) ||Flexion ||Extension / Hyperextension |- || ||Abduction ||Adduction |} {| class="wikitable" |[[Interphalangeal articulations of foot|Interphalangeal]] (toes) ||Flexion ||Extension |} The muscles [[tibialis anterior]] and [[tibialis posterior]] invert the foot. Some sources also state that the [[triceps surae]] and [[extensor hallucis longus]] invert.{{rp|123}} Inversion occurs at the [[subtalar joint]] and [[transverse tarsal joint]].{{cite web |url=http://www.upstate.edu/cdb/grossanat/limbs9.shtml |title=Gross Anatomy: Functional Anatomy Of The Ankle And Foot |accessdate=December 18, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090823072214/http://www.upstate.edu/cdb/grossanat/limbs9.shtml# |archive-date=2009-08-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Eversion of the foot occurs at the [[subtalar joint]]. The muscles involved in this include [[Fibularis longus]] and [[fibularis brevis]], which are innervated by the [[superficial fibular nerve]]. Some sources also state that the [[fibularis tertius]] everts.{{cite book |author=Kyung Won, PhD. Chung |title=Gross Anatomy (Board Review) |publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins |year=2005 |isbn=0-7817-5309-0 |oclc= |doi=}}{{rp|108}} Gray441.png|[[Peroneus longus]] and [[peroneus brevis]] (centre left), the primary muscles involved in eversion Gray442.png|Tibialis anterior and posterior (centre top), the primary muscles involved in inversion Dorsiflexion of the foot: The muscles involved include those of the [[Anterior compartment of leg]], specifically [[tibialis anterior muscle]], [[extensor hallucis longus muscle]], [[extensor digitorum longus muscle]], and [[peroneus tertius]]. The range of motion for dorsiflexion indicated in the literature varies from 12.2{{cite journal |last1=Boone |first1=Donna C. |last2=Azen |first2=Stanley P. |title=Normal range of motion of joints in male subjects |journal=The Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery |date=July 1979 |volume=61-A |pages=756–759 |url=http://jbjs.org/pdfaccess.ashx?ResourceID=23647&PDFSource=17 |accessdate=24 October 2012}} to 18{{cite book|last=American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons|title=Joint Motion: Method of Measuring and Recording|year=1965|publisher=American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons|location=Chicago}} degrees.{{cite journal |last1=Roaas |first1=Asbjørn |last2=Andersson |first2=Gunnar B. J. |title=Normal Range of Motion of the Hip, Knee and Ankle Joints in Male Subjects, 30–40 Years of Age |journal=Acta Orthopaedica |year=1982 |volume=53 |issue=2 |pages=205–208 |url=http://informahealthcare.com/doi/pdf/10.3109/17453678208992202 |doi=10.3109/17453678208992202}} [[Foot drop]] is a condition, that occurs when dorsiflexion is difficult for an individual who is walking. Plantarflexion of the foot: Primary muscles for plantar flexion are situated in the [[Posterior compartment of leg]], namely the superficial [[Gastrocnemius]], [[Soleus]] and [[Plantaris]] (only weak participation), and the deep muscles [[Flexor hallucis longus]], [[Flexor digitorum longus]] and [[Tibialis posterior]]. Muscles in the [[Lateral compartment of leg]] also weakly participate, namely the [[Fibularis longus]] and [[Fibularis brevis]] muscles. Those in the lateral compartment only have weak participation in plantar flexion though. The range of motion for plantar flexion is usually indicated in the literature as 30° to 40°, but sometimes also 50°. The nerves are primarily from the [[Sacral nerves|sacral]] spinal cord roots S1 and S2. Compression of S1 roots may result in weakness in plantarflexion; these nerves run from the lower back to the bottom of the foot. {{citation needed|date=December 2013}} ''[[:wikt:pronation|Pronation]]'' at the [[forearm]] is a rotational movement at the [[Proximal radioulnar articulation|radioulnar joint]], or of the [[foot]] at the [[subtalar joint|subtalar]] and [[talocalcaneonavicular joint]]s.{{cite book |last1=Kendall |first1=F. P. |last2=McCreary |first2=E. K. |last3=Provance |first3=P. G. |title=Muscles Testing and Function |year=1993 |edition=4th |publisher=Lippincott Williams and Wilkins |isbn=0-683-04576-8}}{{cite book |last1=Brukner |first1=P. |last2=Khan |first2=K. |title=Clinical Sports Medicine |year=1993 |edition=1st |publisher=McGraw-Hill Book Company |isbn=0-07-452852-1}} For the forearm, when standing in the [[anatomical position]], pronation will move the palm of the hand from an anterior-facing position to a posterior-facing position without an associated movement at the [[shoulder joint]]). This corresponds to a [[counterclockwise]] twist for the right forearm and a [[clockwise]] twist for the left (when viewed superiorly). In the forearm, this action is performed by [[pronator quadratus]] and [[pronator teres muscle]]. [[Brachioradialis]] puts the forearm into a midpronated/supinated position from either full pronation or supination. For the foot, pronation will cause the sole of the foot to face more laterally than when standing in the anatomical position. Pronation of the foot is a compound movement that combines [[Abduction (kinesiology)|abduction]], [[Eversion (kinesiology)|eversion]], and [[dorsiflexion]]. Regarding posture, a pronated foot is one in which the heel bone angles inward and the arch tends to collapse. Pronation is the motion of the inner and outer ball of the foot with the heel bone.{{cite web |url=http://realhealthynet.com/2012/07/foot-in-the-bottom-of-the-foot/foot-in-the-bottom-of-the-foot/ |title=Foot in the bottom of the foot – RealHealthyNet |publisher=Realhealthynet.com |date=July 11, 2012 |accessdate=August 30, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719182112/http://realhealthynet.com/2012/07/foot-in-the-bottom-of-the-foot/foot-in-the-bottom-of-the-foot/# |archive-date=2013-07-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }} One is said to be "[[knock-kneed]]" if one has overly pronated feet. It flattens the arch as the foot strikes the ground in order to absorb shock when the heel hits the ground, and to assist in balance during mid-stance. If habits develop, this action can lead to foot pain as well as knee pain, [[shin splints]], [[achilles tendinitis]], posterior tibial tendinitis, [[piriformis syndrome]], and [[plantar fasciitis]].{{Citation needed|reason=this is the received wisdom in running, but a citation would be nice.|date=May 2011}}. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Human physiology]] [[Category:Lists of human anatomical features|Movements]]

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
The following is a '''list of [[spreadsheet]]s'''. ==Free and open-source software== ===Cloud and on-line spreadsheets=== {{main|List of online spreadsheets}} * [[Sheetster]] – "Community Edition" is available under the [[Affero GPL]] *[https://www.zoho.com/sheet/ Zoho Sheet] - A simple, collaborative spreadsheet software. * [[Simple Spreadsheet]] * [[Tiki Wiki CMS Groupware]] includes a spreadsheet since 2004 and migrated to jQuery.sheet in 2010.{{Citation | url = http://doc.tiki.org/Spreadsheet | publisher = Tiki | title = Spreadsheet}}. * [[wikiCalc]] (now called SocialCalc) * [[Airtable]] - a spreadsheet-database hybrid, with the features of a database but applied to a spreadsheet. ===Spreadsheets that are parts of suites=== * [[Gnumeric]] — for [[Linux]]. Started as the [[GNOME]] desktop spreadsheet. Reasonably lightweight but has very advanced features.{{Citation | contribution-url = http://www.gnome.org/projects/gnumeric/downloads.shtml | publisher = Gnome | title = Office | contribution = Gnumeric | type = downloads}}. * [[KSpread]] — following the fork of the [[Calligra Suite]] from [[KOffice]] in mid-2010, superseded by [[KCells]] in [[KOffice]] and [[Calligra Sheets|Sheets]] in the Calligra Suite.{{Citation | url = http://www.koffice.org/ | title = The KOffice Project}}. * [[LibreOffice]] [[LibreOffice Calc|Calc]] — developed for MS Windows, GNU/Linux, [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]] and Apple [[OS X|Macintosh]] (Mac) operating systems by [[The Document Foundation]]. The Document Foundation was formed in mid-2010 by several large organisations such as [[Google]], [[Red Hat]], [[Canonical Ltd|Canonical]] ([[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]) and [[Novell]] along with the OpenOffice.org community (developed by [[Sun Microsystems|Sun]]) and various OpenOffice.org forks, notably [[Go-oo]]. Go-oo had been the "OpenOffice" used in Ubuntu and elsewhere. Started as [[StarOffice]] in the late 1990s, it became OpenOffice under [[Sun Microsystems|Sun]] and then LibreOffice in mid-2010. The Document Foundation works with external organisations such as NeoOffice and [[Apache Foundation]] to help drive all three products forward.{{Citation | url = http://www.libreoffice.org/ | title = LibreOffice}}. * [[NeoOffice]] Calc — for Mac. Started as an OpenOffice.org port to Mac, but by using the Mac-specific [[Aqua (user interface)|Aqua]] [[user interface]], instead of the more widely used X11 windowing server, it aimed to be far more stable than the normal ports of other suites.{{Citation | url = http://www.neooffice.org/ | title = NeoOffice}}. * [[OpenOffice.org]] [[OpenOffice.org Calc|Calc]] — for MS Windows, GNU/Linux and the Apple Macintosh. Started as [[StarOffice]]. [[Sun Microsystems|Sun]] changed the name to OpenOffice.org and developed a community of developers (and others) between the late 1990s and mid-2010. Oracle gave it to the Apache Foundation in 2011. IBM contributed their fork of OpenOffice.org, [[IBM Lotus Symphony]], to Apache a few weeks later.{{Citation | url = http://www.openoffice.org/ | title = OpenOffice.org}}. * [[Siag Office|Siag]] — for GNU/Linux, [[OpenBSD]] and Apple Mac OS X. A simple old spreadsheet, part of Siag Office.{{cite web |url=http://siag.nu/siag/ |title= Scheme In A Grid | publisher = Siag | date=2000-12-07 | place = NU | access-date= 7 March 2017}} * [[Calligra Sheets|Sheets]] — for MS Windows, GNU/Linux, [[FreeBSD]], Apple Mac OS X and [[Haiku (operating system)|Haiku]]. Part of the extensive Calligra Suite. Possibly still mainly for Linux, but ports have been developed for other [[operating system]]s.{{Citation | url = http://www.calligra-suite.org/ | title = The Calligra Suite}}. ===Standalone spreadsheets=== * [[GNU Oleo]]{{Citation | contribution-url = https://www.gnu.org/software/oleo/oleo.html | contribution = Oleo software | title = GNU Project | publisher = Free Software Foundation (FSF)}}. * [[Pyspread]]{{Citation | contribution-url = https://manns.github.io/pyspread | title = manns | publisher = Github | contribution = pyspread}}. ==Proprietary software== ===Online spreadsheets=== {{main |List of online spreadsheets}} * [[EditGrid]]{{Citation | url = http://www.editgrid.com/ | title = EditGrid}}. – access, collaborate and share spreadsheets online, with API support; discontinued since 2014 *[https://www.zoho.com/sheet/ Zoho Sheet] - A simple, collaborative spreadsheet software. * [[Google Sheets]] – as part of [[Google Docs]] * [[iRows]]{{Citation | url = http://www.irows.com/ | title = iRows}}. – closed since 31 December 2006 * [[JotSpot]] Tracker{{Citation | url = http://tracker.jot.com/ | publisher = Jot | title = Tracker}}. – acquired by [[Google Inc.]] * [[Smartsheet]]{{Citation | url = http://www.smartsheet.com/ | title = Smartsheet}}. – Online spreadsheet for project management, interactive Gantt, file sharing, integrated with [[Google Apps]]{{citation | url = https://www.google.com/enterprise/marketplace/viewListing?productListingId=3429+4388443950638085375&pli=1 | publisher = Google | title = Apps Marketplace Profile}}. * [[ThinkFree Office|ThinkFree Online]] Calc – as part of the ThinkFree Office online office suite, using [[Java (programming language)|Java]] ===Spreadsheets that are parts of suites=== * [[Ability Office]] Spreadsheet – for MS Windows.{{Citation | url = http://www.ability.com/ | title = Ability Plus Software}}. * [[Apple iWork]] [[Numbers (software)|Numbers]], included with Apple's [[iWork]] '08 suite exclusively for Mac OS X v10.4 or higher. * [[AppleWorks]] – for MS Windows and Macintosh. This is a further development of the historical [[Claris Works]] Office suite.{{Citation | url = https://www.apple.com/appleworks/ | publisher = Apple | title = AppleWorks}}. * [[WordPerfect Office]] [[Quattro Pro]] – for MS Windows. Was one of the big three spreadsheets (the others being Lotus 123 and Excel).{{Citation | url = http://www.corel.com/ | title = Corel}}. * [[EasyOffice]] EasySpreadsheet – for MS Windows. No longer freeware, this suite aims to be more user friendly than competitors.{{Citation | title = E-Press | url = http://www.e-press.com/}}. * [[Framework (office suite)|Framework]] – for MS Windows. Historical office suite still available and supported. It includes a spreadsheet.{{Citation | url = http://www.framework.com/ | title = Framework}}. * [[IBM Lotus Symphony]] – freeware for MS Windows, Apple Mac OS X and GNU/Linux. * [[Kingsoft Office]] Spreadsheets 2012 – For MS Windows. Both free and paid versions are available. It can handle Microsoft Excel .xls and .xlsx files, and also produce other file formats such as .et, .txt, .csv, .pdf, and .dbf. It supports multiple tabs, VBA macro and PDF converting.{{Citation | url = http://www.kingsoftstore.com/spreadsheets.html | publisher = Kingsoft | title = Spreadsheets}}. * [[Lotus SmartSuite]] [[Lotus 123]] – for MS Windows.{{Citation | url = http://www-142.ibm.com/software/sw-lotus/products/product2.nsf/wdocs/sshome | publisher = IBM | title = Office productivity suite Lotus SmartSuite}}. In its MS-DOS (character cell) version, widely considered to be responsible for the explosion of popularity of spreadsheets during the 80s and early 90s.{{Citation needed |date=October 2015}} * [[Mariner software|MarinerPak]] [[Mariner software|Mariner Calc]] – for Apple Macintosh. Full featured and light weight.{{Citation | url = http://www.marinersoftware.com/sitepage.php?page=14 | title = Macintosh Spreadsheet Software | publisher = Mariner Software}}. * [[Microsoft Office]] [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]] – for MS Windows and Apple Macintosh. The proprietary spreadsheet leader.{{Citation | contribution = Excel | title = Office | contribution-url = http://office.microsoft.com/excel/ | publisher = Microsoft}}. * [[Microsoft Works]] Spreadsheet – for MS Windows (previously MS-DOS and Apple Macintosh). Only allows one sheet at a time.{{Citation | url = http://www.microsoft.com/products/works/ | publisher = Microsoft | title = Works}}. * [[PlanMaker]] – for MS Windows, GNU/Linux, MS Windows Mobile and CE; part of [[SoftMaker Office]] * [[Quattro Pro]] – part of [[WordPerfect Office]] * [[StarOffice]] Calc – Cross-platform. StarOffice was originally developed by the German company Star Division which was purchased by [[Sun Microsystems|Sun]] in 1998. The code was made open source and became [[OpenOffice.org]]. Sun continues developing the commercial version which periodically integrates the open source code with their own and third party code to make new low price versions.{{Citation | url = http://www.sun.com/software/star/staroffice/ | title = StarOffice | publisher = Sun}}. ===Stand alone spreadsheets=== * [[As-Easy-As]] – from Trius, Inc.; unsupported; last MS-DOS and Windows versions available with free full license key. * [[Mariner software|Mariner Calc]] for the Apple Macintosh. ===Multi-dimensional spreadsheets=== * [[Javelin Software|Javelin]] * [[Lotus Improv]] * [[Lotus Improv#After Improv|Quantrix Financial Modeler]] ===Spreadsheets on different paradigms=== * [[DADiSP]] – Combines the numerical capability of [[MATLAB]] with a spreadsheet like interface. * [[Javelin Software|Javelin]] * [[Lotus Improv]] * [[Resolver One]] – a business application development tool that represents spreadsheets as [[IronPython]] programs, created and executed in real time and allowing the spreadsheet flow to be fully programmed * [[Spreadsheet 2000]] ===Spreadsheet-related developmental software=== * [[ExtenXLS]] – Java Spreadsheet Toolkit. ==Specifications== {{Expand list|date=August 2008}}

-* [[32-bit]] addressable memory on Microsoft Windows, i.e. ~2.5 GB. ==Historical== * [[VisiCalc]] The first widely used normal spreadsheet with A1 notation etc. * [[Lotus 1-2-3]] Took the market from Visicalc in the early 1980s. * [[Lotus Improv]] Novel design that went beyond A1 notation. * [[Lotus Symphony for DOS]] * [[Multiplan]] Early version of Excel. * [[20/20 (spreadsheet software)|20/20]] Multiplatform competitor to 1-2-3 with database integration and real-time data updating. * [[3D-Calc]] multi-dimensional spreadsheet for [[Atari ST]]{{Citation | url = https://www.medcalc.org/legacysoftware/atari/3dcalc.php | author = Frank Schoonjans| work = Atari ST | title = 3D-Calc }}. * [[SuperCalc]] – [[CP/M]]-80 Included with early Osborne computers. It also was ported to [[MS-DOS]] and to [[Microsoft Windows]]. * [[OS-9|Dynacalc]] — from Computer Systems Center, similar to VisiCalc. It was designed to run on Microware's OS-9, a [[Unix-like]] operating system.{{cite web | format = [[Portable document format|PDF]] |title= Dynacalc | type = manual |url= http://www.colorcomputerarchive.com/coco/Documents/Manuals/Applications/Dynacalc%20%28Tandy%29.pdf |publisher= Tandy |accessdate=April 13, 2015}} * [[Paperback Software International|VP Planner]] – Similar in look and feel to Lotus 1-2-3, but included 5 level multi-dimensional database{{cite book| first1= James | last1 = Stephenson | first2 = Kent | last2 = Brothers | first3 = Dave | last3 = Mitchell | publisher = Paperback Software International, Stephenson Software |title= VP-Planner: Spreadsheet Flexibility with Database Powe|date=December 1, 1986 |isbn= 0-87142021-X }} * [[Informix Wingz|Wingz]] Multi Dimensional preadsheetS from Informix (1988) * [[Boeing Calc]] – was a spreadsheet package written by subsidiary of aviation manufacturer Boeing (1985). ==See also== * [[Comparison of spreadsheets]] * [[Logical spreadsheet]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Spreadsheets}} [[Category:Lists of software|Spreadsheets]] [[Category:Spreadsheet software|*]]

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = National Institute of Oceanography
{{nq|قومی اداره سمندر جغرافیہ}} |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = 1981 |preceding1 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = |headquarters = [[Karachi]], [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]] |coordinates = |region_code = |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = Asif Inam |chief1_position = [[Director General]] |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = [[Ministry of Science and Technology (Pakistan)]] |child1_agency = |website = {{url|niopk.gov.pk}} |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} The '''National Institute of Oceanography (NIO)''', ({{lang-ur|{{nq|قومی اداره سمندر جغرافیہ}}}}), is a department of the [[Government of Pakistan]] and a major research institute of [[Ministry of Science and Technology (Pakistan)]]. The NIO is a science and research executive organization located in [[Karachi]], [[Sindh]], [[Pakistan]]. The NIO' research and studies are funded by the Federal Government of Pakistan while the facilities are provided by the [[Sindh Government]]. ==History== NIO was established in 1981 through a Government Resolution to conduct multidisciplinary research in [[oceanography]] in the coastal and offshore areas of Pakistan (EEZ 24,000 km²). The institute has 30 qualified marine scientists working on ocean biology/productivity, marine chemistry and environment, physical oceanography/coastal hydraulics, marine geology and geophysics. ==Notable people== *[[Hina Baig]] - Senior Research Scientist at the National Institute of Oceanography == See also == * [[Pakistan Antarctic Programme]] * [[Pakistan Meteorological Department]] ==External links== * [http://niopk.gov.pk NIO official website] * [http://most.gov.pk Ministry of Science and Technology] [[Category:Oceanographic organizations]] [[Category:Science and technology in Pakistan]] [[Category:Pakistan Antarctic Programme]] [[Category:Pakistan federal departments and agencies]] [[Category:Science and technology in Karachi]] [[Category:1981 establishments in Pakistan]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 1981]] {{ocean-stub}} {{Pakistan-stub}}

page.title: Online communication between school and home

revision.comment: /* Course Management Systems (CMS) */ put related terms in a 'See also'
revision.text:
[[Wide area network|Online communication]] between [[home]] and [[school]] is the use of [[digital telecommunication]] to convey information and ideas between [[teacher]]s, [[student]]s, [[Parent-teacher conference|parent]]s, and school [[Academic administration|administrators]]. As the use of [[e-mail]] and the [[Internet access|internet]] becomes even more widespread, these tools become more valuable and useful in education for the purposes of increasing [[learning]] for students, and [[facilitation (business)|facilitating]] [[conversation]]s between students, parents, and schools.<ref name=sup7/><ref name=sup8/>
== Overview ==
Online communication emphasizes 21st century skills, [[self-directed learning]], [[self-advocacy]], global awareness, and thinking skills for learners.<ref name="Watson, J. 2009">Watson, J., Gemin, B., & International Association for K-12 Online, L. (2009). Management and Operations of Online Programs: Ensuring Quality and Accountability. Promising Practices in Online Learning. International Association for K-12 Online Learning</ref> Utilizing online communication methods, schools help students develop [[Netiquette]], and technical and [[computer skills]].<ref name="Watson, J. 2009"/><ref name=sup3/> In addition, teachers can provide parents with frequent information about school programs and their children's progress through automated e-mails, official [[website]]s and [[learning management system]]s.<ref name=sup8/><ref name=sup11/> This communication can be achieved either [[synchronization|synchronously]] or [[wikt:asynchronous|asynchronous]]ly, providing greater time flexibility.<ref name=sup11/><ref name=sup9/>
With online communication, learning may occur outside traditional school hours as students participate in collaborative activities, like reading and responding to [[Peer group|peer]] posts in online forums, [[experiment]]s, group [[project]]s, research papers, and current events assignments.<ref name=sup4/> In addition, online communication can connect a wide range of individuals and increase the diversity of [[Perspective (cognitive)|perspective]]s that learners are exposed to.<ref name="Watson, J. 2009"/>
However, not all parents, students, or teachers have access to unlimited [[internet access]] or the digital technology necessary to participate in online communication, and it may be costly to initially implement the [[information technology]], [[Personal computer hardware|hardware]], and [[software]].<ref name=sup1/> Furthermore, schools must provide [[Student orientation|orientation]] to the online environments and [[technical support]] to ensure that all potential [[User (telecommunications)|user]]s are ready to participate.<ref name=sup3/> Teachers will also need to spend additional time online as active participants in the communication activities (e.g. act as the [[Forum moderator#Moderators|moderator]]s of discussions).<ref name="Watson, J. 2009"/><ref name=sup4/> In addition, the immediacy of online communication can lead to students and parents' unreasonable expectations that teachers be 'on-call' at all times.<ref name=sup1>Southern Regional Education Board (2003). Essential Principles of High-Quality Online Teaching: Guidelines for Evaluating K-12 Online Teachers.</ref>
== Online communication between parents and school ==
Online communication between parents and schools are online methods that serve as a [[Computing platform|platform]] for parents and teachers to exchange ideas. For teachers and administrators, online communication makes it easier to reach the parents and build the partnerships with parents.Online communication allows parents to receive real-time information about their child’s performance and activities at school, and flexible opportunities to ask questions and provide information to teachers and school administrators.
In this recent time of technology and modern educational sector, there are many ways to get instant connectivity with your university or college teachers. In the online education process the communication is playing a major role for both teachers and students. There are many online universities and colleges who offer their education services online and they create a good communication path where all the student and the teacher took participation to discuss with every other and this will also help to get problem resolve very early. For those professional employees who stop their studies and start doing work. With the online education colleges and universities now they have an opportunity to get complete their education and complete their academic profile by having a higher degree on their resume. If you have a years of work experience in any field, but your employer doesn’t recognize you just because of your degree then there is a good news for you that the online universities also giving you the chance for apply your degree on the basis of your work experience.
=== Benefits ===
Creating [[Mode (literature)|mode]]s for online communication can increase parent participation in their children's education, which in turn increases students’ interest in their learning. Online communication increases parents’ understanding of classroom [[Procedure (term)|procedures]], [[Philosophy|philosophies]] and [[Policy|policies]]. Parents then feel more involved in their child's school and more connected to the teacher. In general, online communication improves parents’ attitudes toward conferencing with teachers and administrators.<ref name=sup13/><ref name=sup15/><ref name=sup17/><ref name=sup23/>
This style of communication allows for more asynchronous communication and greater flexibility. With online communication, parents can initiate conversations and express concerns to teachers and school officials easily. In addition, informal communication through online [[Online chat|chat]]ting or [[Internet forum|forum]]s can reduce parents’ [[anxiety]] of meeting face-to-face with teachers and/or school officials. When possible, online communication can also offer comfort through anonymity.<ref name=sup13/><ref name=sup15/><ref name=sup17/><ref name=sup23/>
=== Challenges ===
Though most of the time, teachers and parents want to establish communication, there are some challenges that teacher and parents need to face together. The most common challenges involve parent’s ability to use the [[software]], their access to consistent [[internet access]] and [[language barrier]]s. There may be financial costs incurred by the school, if they provide [[training]] or [[translation]] to parents in order to make online communication more inclusive.<ref name=sup13/><ref name=sup15/><ref name=sup23/><ref name=sup24/><ref name=sup24/>
== Online communication between students and teachers ==
Online communication between teachers and students facilitates the exchange of ideas and [[e-learning]]. Online communication allows students to access learning materials beyond school hours and develop relationships with peers and teachers.<ref name=sup31/><ref name=sup32/>
=== Benefits ===
The creation of [[Web 2.0]] and [[social networks]] means that knowledge is now [[collective]] and readily available online for students to access and contribute to.<ref name=sup31/> Promoting online communication between teachers and students creates opportunities for students to receive feedback and assistance from teachers and peers outside the regular school day and classroom. Student can e-mail or post questions, add their opinions to peer-discussions, and check official websites for pertinent information.
Through online learning communities of teachers and peers, students can build relationships with other users and establish a sense of both [[connectedness]] and belonging. Some students, who are less likely to participate in face-to discussions, are more likely to participate in [[online discussion]]s and activities. This online communication enhances the strength of the relationships between students and both their peers and teachers.
=== Challenges ===
Student can demonstrate [[antipathy]] towards online communication or peer [[interdependency]] in internet forums. In order to be productive, online communication between students and teachers requires [[trust (social sciences)|trust]], [[interactivity]], common expectations and shared goals. Some students expect teachers to be on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, placing unreasonable expectations upon teachers.<ref name=sup28/> In addition, most students spend participate in online communication from home, which means that parent's help is often required, but may not be available. Finally, students may lack the technical skills or access to the technology necessary to involve themselves in online communication.
=== Role of teachers ===
Teachers have great responsibility in the establishment of online communication and [[communities]] with students, because of their leadership position. Several of their in-class characteristics must extend into the online environment, such as their ability to guide student behavior and learning. With online communication, teachers must model and demonstrate appropriate Netiquette throughout their persistent involvement. Teachers should also encourage their classes to evolve into [[learning communities]] in which group processes have the power to influence the behavior of individuals.<ref name=sup31/> These online environments should foster a sense of [[openness]], friendliness, and [[Trust (social sciences)|trust]], so that [[problem solving]] becomes a group function.<ref name=sup31/><ref name=sup34/>
=== Examples ===
Teachers and students can e-mail questions and answers to each other about course content and assignments. Schools and teachers can maintain official websites with important information about events, assignments, and resources that students can utilize outside class.<ref name=sup25/><ref name=sup33/><ref name=sup45/>
Both students and teachers can post messages in online forums as a part of homework assignments. In this way they can present different points of view that they don't have any chance to present in the classroom.
Online [[study group]]s allow students to maintain relationships with their peers from a distance. These study groups can be created within a classroom’s [[Social-networking sites|social networking site]], allowing users to connect with each other directly, beyond typical chat rooms and forums.
Teachers can develop [[virtual tour]]s, [[virtual education]], and virtual learning environment for their students in [[Multi-User Virtual Environment|multi-user virtual environment]]s (MUVE).
== Technology and tools ==
The most widely used online communication tool is e-mail between teachers, which provides opportunities for asynchronous communication, instantaneous distribution to a mass audience, mobile access, and file exchange.<ref name=sup39/><ref name=sup40/> Teacher-created websites provide online access to administrative information, calendars, [[Hyperlink|link]]s, [[blog]]s, etc. Internet forums allow learners and teachers to articulate ideas, give and receive feedback, reflect on the perspectives of others, and receive clarification of concepts.<ref name=sup37/> [[List of social networking websites|social networking site]]s are used for focused and open communication between users. Blogs allow individuals to express their ideas in greater detail and with [[multimedia]].
===Course Management Systems (CMS)=== {{See also|Learning management system|Virtual learning environment}}
Various course management systems are designed specifically for facilitating online communication in education. Effective course management software tends to include more information, widgets, functions, and customization options than teacher-created websites.
Most course management systems include: * class information: calendar, [[syllabus]], details of prerequisites, assessment information, and a [[FAQ]] * a notice board with up-to-date course information * learning materials: course content, copies of visual aids, reading materials and links to community resources * assessment opportunities: [[self-assessment]], [[Self- and Peer-Assessment|peer-assessment]], and formal assessment * communication support: e-mail, [[threaded discussion]]s, and a chat room * differentiated access rights for teachers, administrators, and students * document authoring tools * administrative tools: student [[Tracking (education)|tracking]] capabilities, [[statistics]], and [[report]]s
Notable CMS Software include: <!--Entries should have a Wikipedia article, based on multiple independent sources.--> * [[Chamilo]] * [[Claroline]] * [[eFront]] * [[ILIAS]] * [[JoomlaLMS]] (a LMS based on Joomla platform) * [[LAMS]] (Learning Activity Management System) * [[Moodle]] * [[Sakai Project|Sakai]]

[http://blogs.scholastic.com/top_teaching/2010/09/parent-teacher-student-communication-going-beyond-paper-newsletters-and-emails.html Parent, Teacher, Student Communication — Going Beyond Paper Newsletters and Emails]. Retrieved October 10, 2010</ref> <ref name=sup45>[http://www.everythingdsl.com/featured-articles/student-and-teacher-communication How the Internet Has Changed the Student and Teacher Communication - 6 Things They Never Argue About].</ref> }}

{{essay-like|date=November 2018}} {{refimprove|date=November 2018}} [[File:The optical system of the ELT showing the location of the mirrors (no annotation).jpg|thumb|300px|The optical system of the [[European Extremely Large Telescope|ELT]] showing the location of the mirrors.<ref>{{cite web|title=ESO Awards ELT Sensor Contract to Teledyne e2v|url=https://www.eso.org/public/announcements/ann17027/|website=www.eso.org|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref>]]
'''Optical engineering''' is the field of study that focuses on applications of [[optics]]. Optical engineers design components of [[optical instrument]]s such as [[lens (optics)|lenses]], [[microscope]]s, [[telescope]]s, and other equipment that utilizes the properties of [[light]]. Other devices include optical sensors and measurement systems, [[laser]]s, [[fiber optic communication]] systems, [[optical disc]] systems (e.g. [[CD]], [[DVD]]), etc.
Because optical engineers want to design and build devices that make light do something useful, they must understand and apply the science of optics in substantial detail, in order to know what is physically possible to achieve ([[physics]] and [[chemistry]]). However, they also must know what is practical in terms of available technology, materials, costs, design methods, etc. As with other fields of engineering, [[computer]]s are important to many (perhaps most) optical engineers. They are used with instruments, for simulation, in design, and for many other applications. Engineers often use general computer tools such as [[spreadsheet]]s and [[programming language]]s, and they make frequent use of specialized optical software designed specifically for their field.
Optical engineering [[metrology]] uses optical methods to measure micro-vibrations with instruments like the laser speckle interferometer or to measure the properties of the various masses with instruments measuring [[refraction]].
==See also== *[[Optical lens design]] *[[Optical physics]] *[[Optician]]
==References== {{reflist}}

Walker, Historical Review,SPIE Press, Bellingham, WA. {{ISBN|978-0-8194-7877-1}}. [http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160514130627/http://link.aip.org/link/doi/10.1117/3.818136.ch2] * FTS Yu & Xiangyang Yang (1997) ''Introduction to Optical Engineering'', [[Cambridge University Press]], {{ISBN|0-521-57493-5}}. * [http://spie.org/x867.xml?WT.svl=mddp13 Optical Engineering] ([[International_Standard_Serial_Number|ISSN]] [http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=0091-3286&qt=results_page 0091-3286])

{{Infobox book | name = Pathological Altruism | image = Pathological Altruism.jpg | title_orig = | translator = | editor = Barbara A. Oakley, Ariel Knafo, Guruprasad Madhavan, David Sloan Wilson | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = Psychology | genre = Non-fiction | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | pub_date = 5 January 2012 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 496 | isbn = 978-0-19-973857-1 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Pathological Altruism''''' is a book edited by [[Barbara Oakley]], Ariel Knafo, Guruprasad Madhavan, and [[David Sloan Wilson]]. It was published on 5 January 2012 by Oxford University Press, and contains 31 academic papers. Oakley defines pathological altruism as "altruism in which attempts to promote the welfare of others instead result in unanticipated harm."{{cite web|last=Taranto |first=James |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324688404578545523824389986 |title=Best of the Web Today: Pathological Altruism |work=Wall Street Journal |date=2013-06-14 |accessdate=2015-11-10}} ==Overview== The book comprises a collection of essays which discuss negative aspects of [[altruism]] and [[empathy]] towards others, such as when altruism hurts the altruist, is taken to an unhealthy extreme, or causes more harm than good. Examples given include depression and burnout seen in healthcare professionals, an unhealthy focus on others to the detriment of one's own needs, hoarding of animals, and ineffective philanthropic and social programs that ultimately worsen the situations they are meant to aid. It is considered the first book to explore negative aspects of [[altruism]] and empathy.{{cite web|url=http://ukcatalogue.oup.com/product/9780199738571.do |title=Pathological Altruism: Hardback: Barbara Oakley |publisher=Oxford University Press |date=2012-01-05 |accessdate=2015-10-27}} According to Oakley, [[anorexia]], supporting addictions of other people ([[codependency]]), animal hoarding, depression, guilt and self-righteousness can be pathological altruism. Oakley has also stated that suicide bombings and genocides can be caused by pathological altruism, when perpetrators of these acts believe they are behaving altruistically towards those who share their ideology.{{cite web|last=Habash |first=Gabe |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/tip-sheet/article/49893-when-kindness-attacks-a-q-a-with-barbara-oakley.html |title=When Kindness Attacks: A Q&A with Barbara Oakley |work=Publishersweekly.com |date=2011-12-16 |accessdate=2015-11-10}} Oakley further states that some people are naturally "hypersensitive" or they have an excessive desire to "help" others. According to Oakley, such people are convinced that they are helping others without considering the practical results of their "help". ==Sections== # The psychology of pathological altruism # Psychiatric implications of pathological altruism # Societal implications of pathological altruism # Cultural and evolutionary dimensions of pathological altruism # The development and underlying brain processes of pathological altruism # Synthesis of views on pathological altruism ==Reviews== The book was widely reviewed, including reviews in the ''New Scientist'',{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg21128290-300-the-dark-side-of-altruism/ |title=The dark side of altruism |work=New Scientist |date=2011-09-07 |accessdate=2015-10-27}} and ''The Independent''.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/features/are-we-killing-people-with-kindness-6256124.html |title=Are we killing people with kindness?|work=The Independent |date=2011-11-06 |accessdate=2015-10-27}} ''Nursing Standard'' said "I recommend this book to health professionals looking for a deeper understanding of altruism and its motivation. The arguments are clear and scholarly, and supported by a wealth of references." Writing in ''The New York Times'', Natalie Angier called book a "scholarly yet surprisingly sprightly volume". She wrote,
pathological altruism is not limited to showcase acts of self-sacrifice... The book is the first comprehensive treatment of the idea that when ostensibly generous 'how can I help you?' behavior is taken to extremes, misapplied or stridently rhapsodized, it can become unhelpful, unproductive and even destructive. Selflessness gone awry may play a role in a broad variety of disorders, including anorexia and animal hoarding, women who put up with abusive partners and men who abide alcoholic ones. Because a certain degree of selfless behavior is essential to the smooth performance of any human group, selflessness run amok can crop up in political contexts. It fosters the exhilarating sensation of righteous indignation, the belief in the purity of your team and your cause and the perfidiousness of all competing teams and causes.{{cite news|title=The Pathological Altruist Gives Till Someone Hurts|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/04/science/04angier.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=10 November 2015|work=The New York Times}}
==See also== * [[Altruism]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|author=Barbara Oakley|title=Pathological Altruism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FPtwdmXtjmoC|date=5 January 2012|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-973857-1}} ==External links== * [http://ukcatalogue.oup.com/product/9780199738571.do Oxford University Press catalogue listing] * [http://www.barbaraoakley.com/pa.html Page about the book on Barbara Oakley's website] [[Category:2012 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Science books]] [[Category:Psychology books]]

{{refimprove|date=August 2016}} {{Use American English|date=March 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}}
{{Main article|Pioneer Venus Orbiter|Pioneer Venus Multiprobe}}
[[File:Venuspioneeruv.jpg|thumb|Cloud structure in [[Atmosphere of Venus|the Venusian atmosphere]] in 1979, revealed by ultraviolet observations by [[Pioneer Venus Orbiter]]]] The '''Pioneer Venus project''' was part of the [[Pioneer program]] consisting of two spacecraft, the [[Pioneer Venus Orbiter]] and the [[Pioneer Venus Multiprobe]], launched to [[Venus]] in 1978. The program was managed by [[NASA]]'s [[Ames Research Center]]. An official Ames documentary film titled "Venus Pioneers" is visible on George Van Valkenburg's YouTube Channel.
The Pioneer Venus Orbiter entered orbit around Venus on December 4, 1978, and performed observations to characterize the [[Atmosphere of Venus|atmosphere]] and surface of Venus. It continued to transmit data until October 1992.
The Pioneer Venus Multiprobe deployed four small probes into the Venusian atmosphere on December 9, 1978. All four probes transmitted data throughout their descent to the surface. One probe survived landing and transmitted data from the surface for over an hour.
==Overview== The Pioneer mission consisted of two components, launched separately: an orbiter and a multiprobe.
===Orbiter=== {{main article|Pioneer Venus Orbiter}} The orbiter was launched on 20 May 1978 with an Atlas-Centaur rocket. The orbiter's mass was {{convert|517|kg|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Intro">{{cite web |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/pioneer_venus.html |title=Pioneer Venus Project Information |work=NASA Goddard Space Flight Center |accessdate=2016-08-17 }}</ref> The Pioneer Venus Orbiter was inserted into an elliptical orbit around Venus on December 4, 1978. It carried 17 experiments (with a total mass of 45 kg):<ref name="Intro"/> *a cloud photopolarimeter to measure the vertical distribution of the clouds *a surface radar mapper to determine topography and surface characteristics *an infrared radiometer to measure IR emissions from the Venus atmosphere *an airglow ultraviolet spectrometer to measure scattered and emitted UV light *a neutral mass [[spectrometer]] to determine the composition of the upper atmosphere *a [[solar wind]] plasma analyzer to measure properties of the solar wind *a [[magnetometer]] to characterize the magnetic field at Venus *an electric field detector to study the solar wind and its interactions *an electron temperature probe to study the thermal properties of the [[ionosphere]] *an ion [[mass spectrometer]] to characterize the ionospheric ion population *a charged particle retarding potential analyzer to study ionospheric particles *two radio science experiments to determine the gravity field of Venus *a radio occultation experiment to characterize the atmosphere *an atmospheric drag experiment to study the upper atmosphere *a radio science atmospheric and solar wind turbulence experiment *a gamma ray burst detector to record [[gamma-ray burst]] events
In May 1992 the orbiter began the final phase of its mission, in which the periapsis was held between 150 and 250 km until the fuel ran out and atmospheric entry destroyed the spacecraft in August 1992.<ref name="Intro"/>
===Multiprobe=== {{main article|Pioneer Venus Multiprobe}} The Pioneer Venus Multiprobe was launched on August 8, 1978 on an Atlas-Centaur rocket. It consisted of a 290 kg [[Satellite bus|bus]] which carried one large (315 kg) and three small atmospheric probes. The large probe was released on November 16, 1978 and the three small probes on November 20. All four probes entered the Venus atmosphere on December 9, followed by the bus.
The Pioneer Venus large probe was about 1.5 m in diameter and equipped with 7 science experiments. After deceleration from initial atmospheric entry at about 11.5 km/s, a parachute was deployed at 47 km altitude. The science experiments were:<ref name="Intro"/> *a neutral [[mass spectrometer]] to measure the atmospheric composition *a [[gas chromatograph]] to measure the atmospheric composition *a [[Radiant flux|solar flux radiometer]] to measure solar flux penetration in the atmosphere *an infrared radiometer to measure distribution of infrared radiation *a cloud particle size spectrometer to measure particle size and shape *a [[nephelometer]] to search for cloud particles *temperature, pressure, and acceleration sensors
The three small probes were identical to each other, 0.8 m in diameter and 90 kg each small probe.<ref name="Intro"/> The small probes were each targeted at different parts of the planet;<ref>[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/pvprobes.html Pioneer Venus Probes]. NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, 2005.</ref> They had no parachutes and the aeroshells did not separate from the probe.
The Pioneer Venus [[Satellite bus|bus]] also carried two experiments, a neutral [[mass spectrometer]] and an ion mass spectrometer to study the composition of the atmosphere. With no heat shield or parachute, the bus made measurements only to about 110 km altitude before burning up.<ref name="Intro"/>
==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[1978 in spaceflight]] * [[Vega program]] * [[Venera|Venera program]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Pioneer Venus project}} * [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/pioneer_venus.html NASA: Pioneer Venus Project Information] * [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/missions/profile.cfm?MCode=Pioneer_Venus Pioneer Venus Program Page] by [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov NASA's Solar System Exploration] * [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/database/MasterCatalog?sc=1978-078A NSSDC Master Catalog: Spacecraft Pioneer Venus Probe Bus]. (Other components of the mission have their own pages at this site too.) * [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/pvdata.html Pioneer Venus] specifications at NASA * "[https://archive.org/details/nasa_techdoc_19900013957 The Pioneer Venus Orbiter: 11 years of data.]" Results published in May 1, 1990. *[http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/multimedia/display.cfm?Category=Spacecraft&IM_ID=16510 Art for the mission]
